Rationale
Change to module coordinator
Blurb
Overview
This is the MSc Research Project Module. Students will work under supervision of an Academic on a research project related to their specific programme of study. Projects are generally either lab, field or computer based (or a combination).

Students are expected to work independently, with guidance provided by their supervisor. Students will create a plan of work at the start of the project, and will present their work orally, as well as write a final project report. Students will also be assessed on their approach and technique during the project. Students will defend their work in a viva at the end of the module. This module will give students experience in conducting their own independent research project, and the presentation of this work through oral and written formats.

The module takes place at the end of the MSc programme i.e. in the summer semester.
Educational Aims
To give students the opportunity to work in a guided but independent fashion on an area of research related to their programme of study, making use of the knowledge and skills acquired elsewhere in the programme.
Marketing Module Synopsis
In this module students will work on a research project in their chosen area of study under the supervision of a project supervisor. Students are expected to work independently, with guidance provided by their supervisor. Students will create a plan of work at the start of the project, and will present their work orally, as well as write a final project report. Students will also be assessed on their approach and technique during the project. Students will defend their work in a viva at the end of the module. This module will give students experience in conducting their own independent research project, and the presentation of this work through oral and written formats.
Outline Syllabus
The syllabus includes the following elements: planning and carrying out a research project, presentation of the research project orally and in a final report, defence of the project in a viva. The project may be laboratory, field or computer based, with relevant practical experimentation/data analysis, or could be in the form of research of literature.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Lab work
Description: Laboratory / Practical work to support project. Could include wet lab work, field work, computational work depending on the nature of the project.
Attendance Recorded: No

Direct Supervision
Description: Supervision during laboratory/practical work
Attendance Recorded: No

Tutorial
Description: Regular progress meetings with project supervisor
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Self-directed learning
Description: Independent study including background reading, project write-up.
Attendance Recorded: No

The teaching staff on this module varies each year as the research projects being undertaken change in accordance with student interests. Students will work under supervision of an academic on a research project related to their specific programme of study.

Curriculum 2021 hallmarks addressed:
- Research connected teaching. Students are supervised by a research supervisor, and carry out an independent research project.
- Active learning. Students will actively carry out a research project.
- Confidence. Students will work independently on their MSc research project, allowing them to build their confidence

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via five assessments:

A preliminary project plan
A presentation
A final report
A viva
Assessment of the student's approach and technique.

Resit strategy: resit opportunity will be given for each assessment and will have the same format and content as the original assessment. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission. Pass mark is 50.
Further details on the assessments are on the table below.

Curriculum 2021 hallmarks addressed:
- Research-connected teaching. Students will be assessed on their approach and technique, and will create a final project write-up of their research project.
- Authentic Assessment. Students will write final project write-up, will perform a viva, and will present their work orally.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Admin
Marked for Rollover
No

Life702 has been removed as a pre-requisite for this module.

Outcomes
Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 ​Plan a piece of original scientific research;
 LO2 ​Design and perform a coherent set of investigations to test a hypothesis;
 LO3 ​Present work in the form of an oral presentation to a scientific audience and at an oral examination;
 LO4 ​Write final report in the form of a manuscript that would be suitable for submission as a scientific publication.
Skills
 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 ​Research management: developing a research strategy, project planning and delivery, risk management, formulating questions, selecting literature, using primary / secondary / diverse sources, collecting and using data, applying research methods, applying ethics.
 S2 ​Self-management: readiness to accept responsibility (that is, leadership), flexibility, resilience, self-starting, initiative, integrity, willingness to take risks, appropriate assertiveness, time management, readiness to improve own performance based on feedback / reflective learning;
 S3 ​Team (group) working: respecting others, co-operating, negotiating / persuading, awareness of interdependence with others.

Rationale
Change to module coordinator
Blurb
Overview
This is the MSc Research Project Module. Students will work under supervision of an Academic on a research project related to their specific programme of study. Projects are generally either lab, field or computer based (or a combination).

Students are expected to work independently, with guidance provided by their supervisor. Students will create a plan of work at the start of the project, and will present their work orally, as well as write a final project report. Students will also be assessed on their approach and technique during the project. Students will defend their work in a viva at the end of the module. This module will give students experience in conducting their own independent research project, and the presentation of this work through oral and written formats.

The module takes place at the end of the MSc programme i.e. in the summer semester.
Educational Aims
To give students the opportunity to work in a guided but independent fashion on an area of research related to their programme of study, making use of the knowledge and skills acquired elsewhere in the programme.
Marketing Module Synopsis
In this module students will work on a research project in their chosen area of study under the supervision of a project supervisor. Students are expected to work independently, with guidance provided by their supervisor. Students will create a plan of work at the start of the project, and will present their work orally, as well as write a final project report. Students will also be assessed on their approach and technique during the project. Students will defend their work in a viva at the end of the module. This module will give students experience in conducting their own independent research project, and the presentation of this work through oral and written formats.
Outline Syllabus
The syllabus includes the following elements: planning and carrying out a research project, presentation of the research project orally and in a final report, defence of the project in a viva. The project may be laboratory, field or computer based, with relevant practical experimentation/data analysis, or could be in the form of research of literature.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Lab work
Description: Laboratory / Practical work to support project. Could include wet lab work, field work, computational work depending on the nature of the project.
Attendance Recorded: No

Direct Supervision
Description: Supervision during laboratory/practical work
Attendance Recorded: No

Tutorial
Description: Regular progress meetings with project supervisor
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Self-directed learning
Description: Independent study including background reading, project write-up.
Attendance Recorded: No

The teaching staff on this module varies each year as the research projects being undertaken change in accordance with student interests. Students will work under supervision of an academic on a research project related to their specific programme of study.

Curriculum 2021 hallmarks addressed:
- Research connected teaching. Students are supervised by a research supervisor, and carry out an independent research project.
- Active learning. Students will actively carry out a research project.
- Confidence. Students will work independently on their MSc research project, allowing them to build their confidence

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via five assessments:

A preliminary project plan
A presentation
A final report
A viva
Assessment of the student's approach and technique.

Resit strategy: resit opportunity will be given for each assessment and will have the same format and content as the original assessment. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission. Pass mark is 50.
Further details on the assessments are on the table below.

Curriculum 2021 hallmarks addressed:
- Research-connected teaching. Students will be assessed on their approach and technique, and will create a final project write-up of their research project.
- Authentic Assessment. Students will write final project write-up, will perform a viva, and will present their work orally.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes
Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 ​Plan a piece of original scientific research;
 LO2 ​Design and perform a coherent set of investigations to test a hypothesis;
 LO3 ​Present work in the form of an oral presentation to a scientific audience and at an oral examination;
 LO4 ​Write final report in the form of a manuscript that would be suitable for submission as a scientific publication.
Skills
 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 ​Research management: developing a research strategy, project planning and delivery, risk management, formulating questions, selecting literature, using primary / secondary / diverse sources, collecting and using data, applying research methods, applying ethics.
 S2 ​Self-management: readiness to accept responsibility (that is, leadership), flexibility, resilience, self-starting, initiative, integrity, willingness to take risks, appropriate assertiveness, time management, readiness to improve own performance based on feedback / reflective learning;
 S3 ​Team (group) working: respecting others, co-operating, negotiating / persuading, awareness of interdependence with others.
